titleStmt.title: The Grand Question debated
Whether Hamilton's Bawn shall be turn'd
into a Barrack or a Malthouse. \notes apparently: from Sr Ar: Acheson's seat and a large old house\

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Thus spoke to my Lady, the Knight, full of care,
Let me have your advice in a weighty affair:
This Hamilton's Bawn, while it sticks on my hand,
I loose by the house, what I get by the Land,
But how to dispose of it to the best Bidder,
For a Barrack, or Malthouse, we now must consider.First let me suppose I make it a Malthouse,
Here, I have computed the profit will fall t'us:
There's nine hundred pounds for Labour and Grain,
I increase it to twelve so three hundred remain:
An handsome addition for Wine & good Chear,
Three dishes a day, & three Hogsheads a year;
With a dozen large Vessels my Vaults shall be stor'd
No little scrub joynt shall cover my board
And You and the Dean no more shall combine
To stint me at night to one bottle of Wine,
Nor I for his humour permit You to purloin.
A stone & an half of good beef from my Surloin.If I make it a Barrack the Crown is my Tenant,
My Dear I have ponder'd again & again 'ont:
In poundage & drawbacks I loose half my Rent,
Whatever they give me, I must be content,
Or join with the Court in every debate,
And rather than that I would loose my Estate.Thus ended the Knight, thus began his Meek Wife,
It must, and it shall be a Barrack, my Life,
I'me grown a mere Mopus, no Company comes,
But a rabble of Tenants, & rusty dull 1a Cant word in Ireland for poor Country Parsons sidenoteRumms;
With Parsons what Lady can keep herself clean?
I'me all over dawb'd when I sit by the Dean;
But if You will give us a Barrack, my Dear,
The Captain, I'me sure, will always come here;
I then, shall not value his Deanship a Straw,
For the Captain, I warrant, will keep him in awe;
Or should he pretend, to be brisk & alert,
Will tell him that Chaplains, must not be so pert;
That Men of his Coat, should be minding their Prayers,
And not amongst Ladies, to give Themselves Airs.Thus argued my Lady, but argued in vain,
The Knight, his opinion, resolv'd to maintain,But Hannah, who listned, to all that had pass'd,
And could not indure so vulgar a Taste;
As soon as her Ladyship call'd to be dress'd,
Cry'd, Madam, why sure my Master's possess'd:
Sr Arthur the Malster: how fine it will sound:
I'de rather the Bawn, were sunk under ground:
But Madam I guess't there would never come Good,
When I saw him so often, with 2Sr Ar's Managers. Norwood & 3cue to prev. note Wood.
And now my Dream's out; for I was a dream'd,
That I say an huge Rat; o dear how I scream'd;
And after methought I lost my new Shoes,
And Molly, she said, I should hear some ill Newes.Dear Madam, had You, but the Spirit to teize;
You might have a Barrack, whenever you please;
And Madam I always believ'd You so stout
That for twenty denyalls You would not give out;
If I had a Husband like him, I purtest,
Till he gave me my Will, I would give him no rest:
And rather than come, in the same pair of Sheets,
With such a cross Man, I would lye in the Streets;
But Madam I beg You contrive, & invent,
And worry him out, till he gives his Consent;Dear Madam when e're, of a Barrack I think,
An I were to be hang'd, I can't sleep a Wink;
For if a new Crotchet comes into my Brain,
I can't get it out though I'de never so fain,
I fancy a Barrack already contriv'd,
At Hamilton's Bawn, & the Troop is arriv'd.
Of this to be sure, Sr Arthur has warning
And waits on the Captain, betimes the next morning.
Now see when they meet, how their Honours behave,
Noble Captain your Servant──────Sr Arthur your Slave,
You honour me much──────The Honour is mine──
Twas a sad rainey night──────but the morning is fine──
Pray how does my Lady──────My Wife's at your Service──
I think I have seen her Picture by Iervis──────
Good morrow Good Captain, I'll wait on you down──
You shan't stir a foot────You'll think me a Clown──
For all the world Captain, not half an inch farther──
You must be obey'd, your Servant Sr Arthur;
My humble respects to my Lady unknown,──
I hope you will use my house as Your own.Next day, to be sure the Captain will come
At the head of his Troop with Trumpet & Drum,
Now Madam observe, how he marches in State,
The Man with Kettle drum enters the Gate,
Dub a dub, Dub a Dub, the Trumpeters follow
Tantara Tantara, while all the Boys Hollow:
See, now comes the Captain all dawb'd with Gold Lace;
O law, the sweet Gentleman, look in his Face;
And see how he rides like a Lord of the Land
With the fine flaming Sword that he has in his hand;
And his Horse the dear Cretor it prances & rears,
With Ribons in knots at It's Tail, & It's Ears.
At last comes the Troop by the word of Command
Drawn up in our Court, till the Captain crys, stand.
Your Ladyship lifts up the sash to be seen,
For sure I had dizen'd You out like a Queen:
The Captain to shew he is proud of the Favour
Looks up to Your Window & cocks up his Bever:
(His Bever is cockt pray Madam, mark that;
For a Captain of Horse ne're takes of his Hat,
Because he has never a hand that is idle,
For the right holds his sword, & the left holds his Bridle)
Then flourishes thrice, his Sword, in the Air,
As a Compliment due to a Lady so fair,
How I tremble to think of the blood it has spilt,
Then he lowers down the Point, & kisses the Hilt.
Your Ladyship smiles, & thus You begin;
Pray Captain be pleas'd to light & walk in.
The Captain salutes You with Congee profound
And Your Ladyship Curtsey's, half way to the ground.Kitt run to Your Master & bid him come to us,
I'me sure He'll be proud of this Honour You do us.
And Captain You'll do us the favour to stay
And take a short dinner here with us to day;
You're heartily Welcome: but as for Good Chear
You've come in the very worst time in the Year.
If I had but expected so worthy a Guest────
Lord──Madam──Your Ladyship sure is in jest
You banter me Madam────the Kingdom must grant────
You Officers Captain are so Complaisant────To shorten my Tale (for I hate a long story)
The Captain at dinner appears in his Glory──
The Dean, & the 4Dr Jenny an eminent Clergy man at Armagh Dr, have humbled their Pride,
For the Captain's, entreated to sit by your side.
And because he's their Betters, You carve for him first:
The Parsons for envy are ready to burst.
The Servants amaz'd, are scarce ever able,
To keep of they Eyes, as they wait at the Table.
And Molly & I have thrust in our Nose,
To peep at the Captain in all his fine Cloaths.
Dear Madam, be sure, He's a fine spoken Man,
Do but hear on the Clergymen how his Tongue ran;
Poor Creatures they both were as dull as a log,
And had not a word to throw at a dog;
And Madam says He, if such dinners You give,
You'll never want Parsons, as long as You Live:
I ne're knew a Parson with·out a good Nose,
But the Devil's as Welcome, whereever he goes:
G──d d──mn me thy bid us reform & repent
But Z──ds by their looks, they never keep Lent.
Mister Curate for all your Grave looks, I'me afraid,
You cast a Sheep's Eye on her Ladyship's Maid.
I wish she would lent You her pretty white hand,
In mending your Gown, & smoothing your Band.
(For the Dean was so shabby, & look'd like a Ninny,
That the Captain suppos'd he was Curate to Jenny.)Never since I was born did I hear so much Witt,
And Madam I laugh'd till I thought I should split,
So then You look'd scornfull & sniff'd at the Dean,
As who should say now am I skinny & lean;
But he durst not so much as once open his Lips;
And the Doctor was plaguily deep in the Hips.Thus mercyless Hannah, ran on in her Talk,
Till she heard the Dean, call, will your Ladyship walk?
Her Ladyship answers, I'me just coming down,
Then turning to Hannah. & forcing a Frown,
Although it was plain in her heart she was glad,
Cry'd Huzzy why sure the Wench is gone Mad:
How could these Chimaera's get into your Brains,
Come hither & take this old Gown for your pains.
But the Dean, if this secret should come to his Ears,
Will never have done with his Gibes, & his Iears.
For Your Life not a word of the matter I charge Yee
Give me but a Barrack, a Fig for the Clergy.866-001Y
